title: COULD TRUMP TRIGGER A SILICON VALLEY BRAIN DRAIN?
content:
Though some tech leaders have begun to offer dutiful congratulations to president-elect Donald Trump , an air of uncertainty hangs over Silicon Valley . Earlier this year , Trump vowed that he would “ end forever the use of the H-1B as a cheap labor program , ” which the tech industry relies on , “ and institute an absolute requirement to hire American workers first for every visa and immigration program . No exceptions. ” Others within Trump ’ s orbit have similarly called to put American workers first . “ Half of STEM graduates are not finding jobs in STEM fields , ” railed Alabama senator Jeff Sessions , who Trump tapped on Friday to lead the Justice Department , in a 2015 interview . Congress , he said , is “ oblivious ” to the “ reality of what ’ s happening . ”
It goes without saying that it ’ s virtually impossible to know what Trump will actually do once he assumes office . Last year , he actually argued that America needed to do more to keep high-skilled international students in the country after graduation . But the president-elect hasn ’ t clarified his remarks since railing against immigration on the campaign trail , leaving Silicon Valley in the dark and leading foreign competitors to make a play for the same international workers that the tech industry so desperately needs . Just as London , Europe ’ s financial capital , saw an exodus of financial institutions and financiers in the wake of the Brexit vote , so too could tech hubs across the United States struggle to attract talent with Trump in the White House .
China , for one , is not wasting any time in courting would-be Silicon Valley employees . “ I hope that talent in all countries can come to China , and give us a more important role on the stage of global innovation , ” Robin Li , the C.E.O . of Baidu , China ’ s answer to Google , said at a keynote address on Friday . “ The global center of innovation is shifting. ” Li also referenced remarks made by chief Trump strategist Steve Bannon , who has suggested that there are already too many Asian tech C.E.O.s in the U.S. “ I read that an adviser to President-elect Donald Trump complained that three-quarters of engineers in Silicon Valley aren ’ t Americans , ” Li said . “ So I myself hope that many of these engineers will come to China to work for us . ”
Canada , too , stands to capitalize on Trump ’ s unique brand of creative disruption . “ Is this the reversal of the talent diaspora that Canada has historically seen & beginning of the U.S. brain drain ? ” tweeted Hootsuite founder Ryan Holmes , whose company is based in Vancouver . Holmes added that last week after the election , he received calls from five different potential U.S. candidates who were looking to move to Canada . International students are also said to be reconsidering coming to the U.S. to study . “ In his campaign , he ’ s discriminating against Muslim and other brown and black people , ” one student in New Delhi told The New York Times . “ I ’ m thinking of applying to Canada. ” Jocelyne Younan , the director of global undergraduate recruitment at McGill University in Montreal , told the Times she had seen a surge in interest from abroad since Trump ’ s election . “ We have seen an increase in applications from the U.S. and from international students in the last week . We ’ ve also seen an increase in students inquiring about McGill on social media. ” A vice president at the University of Toronto said traffic to their Web site for international applicants spiked from around 1,000 hits per day to 10,000 on November 9 .
